info.author: Jazeps Basko
info.description:
configmanager-cli
=================

An example application of configmanager_ -- a command-line interface (built using click_) to inspect and manage
configuration.

.. image:: https://travis-ci.org/jbasko/configmanager-cli.svg?branch=master
    :target: https://travis-ci.org/jbasko/configmanager-cli


Quick Start
-----------

.. code-block:: shell

    pip install configmanager-cli

    config <config_spec> --help

User Guide
----------

.. code-block:: shell

    > config <config_spec> --help

    Usage: config [OPTIONS] CONFIG_SPEC COMMAND [ARGS]...

    Options:
      --help  Show this message and exit.

    Commands:
      dump         Write configuration values to stdout or a...
      get          Get value of a single configuration item.
      interactive  Update configuration interactively.
      items        List all configuration items.
      reset        Reset all configuration item values to...
      sections     List all configuration sections.
      set          Set value of a configuration item.
      values       List current values of all configuration...


*configmanager-cli* takes a description of your configuration tree and generates a command-line interface (using click_).
As a description of configuration tree it accepts anything that could be acceptable by *configmanager*'s ``Config``, or
what points to something acceptable by ``Config``. In other words, ``<config_spec>`` can be:

* Python module name
* Python module name plus name of a ``Config`` instance in it
* Name of a setuptools entrypoint of group ``config_managers`` which points to an instance of ``Config``
* Path to to a plain text configuration file with a supported extension (``.json``, ``.js``, ``.yaml``, ``.yml``,
  and ``.ini``).

``<config_spec>`` is used only to load defaults and any changes to configuration values will be written elsewhere --
to a dedicated location in user's home directory -- ``~/.config/configmanager/<config_spec>.json``. We use JSON
format by default. You don't have to remember this path as the customisations will automatically get loaded from there
as long as you consistently refer to your ``<config_spec>`` with the same name. Even if you want to forget customisations,
you don't need to know the path as you can do that with the ``reset`` command:

.. code-block:: shell

    > config <config_spec> reset

Examples
--------

.. code-block:: shell

    config configmanager_cli.examples.ex01 --help


.. _configmanager: https://github.com/jbasko/configmanager
.. _click: http://click.pocoo.org/6/
info.name: configmanager-cli
info.summary: Command-line interface to inspect and manage config files using configmanager
